Posted: September 16, 2015
												I really, really wanted to like this game. A surreal, creepy take on the Zelda formula set in its protagonist's subconscious? Sign me up. Unfortunately, Anodyne fails not just at being a "deep" experience but at being a functional game.Hit detection is terrible. The worst I've ever seen in a professional game. It's incredibly frustrating, especially when the game frequently demands pixel perfect movements from the player. It's tolerable until the jump boots are introduced, at which point I was frequently subjected to the clumsiest, buggiest platforming I've ever seen. Countless times my character would land on the edge of a platform, only to hang there for a second and then "slide" off. Either they didn't playtest this at all, or they were comfortable with such awful core gameplay. Not sure which is worse.The creators implemented mercy invincibility, but seem unclear on the purpose of it. Your character is invincible for a fraction of a second after being hit, but flashes for much longer than that. Expect to take damage from the same enemy/attack 3-4 times before you can move him. Even regular enemies enjoy a much longer window of invincibility than you, making combat much slower and more annoying than it needed to be. Enemy attacks carry a huge amount of knockback, frequently ruining attempts at platforming sections.The game is divided into about 50% dungeon crawling and 50% combing the map for cards. The former is irritating because of the above mentioned problems. Puzzles are very simple; there wasn't a single one that required an ounce of thought once I had figured out the central mechanic. (Oh, I jump on this to make it move...time to do that 1000 times.) Bosses (with the exception of the more ambitious but terribly designed final boss) can be beaten just by rushing them and hitting them faster than they hit you. There's no strategy required, and you only have a single attack for the entire game.Hunting for cards (which is mandatory) is a transparent way of extending the game's runtime. A few are cleverly hidden. The rest are just crammed in the most obscure, closed off nooks and crannies of the map. The cards do nothing besides unlock health containers, and, eventually, the path to the final boss. Even with this padding, Anodyne is very short. My blind playthrough, 100%ing the game and taking my time, took about five hours.For a Zelda ripoff, Anodyne contains very few usable items. You get a broom (your weapon) and jump boots. Two optional upgrades very slightly change your broom's range, which feels like a cruel joke on anyone who wanted a varied gameplay experience. The only remotely novel gameplay element is an item that lets you swap two tiles, but it can only be used on a single, incredibly dull puzzle. Beating the game lets you use it anywhere, but since the only thing left to do at that point is go find more cards, I've yet to touch the post game content.On the more superficial side of things, a lot of the buzz surrounding this game concerned its graphics and soundtrack. The graphics are fine if you're not tired of the whole 16 bit tribute thing by now. Apparently the main character wears a hoodie; I didn't realize this until it was pointed out in dialog. Most of the animations look sloppy.As for the music, it is an absolute insult that the OST is being sold for $5. Anodyne has the worst "retro" game soundtrack I've ever heard: just tinny, low quality attempts at chiptunes. Nearly all of the tracks are short loops. Most of them are just forgettable in the "might as well be white noise" sense. A few stand out as so awful I had to mute the game to make it through their respective areas. Even if I loved this game, I wouldn't spend a cent on the soundtrack.As far as the plot, writing, atmosphere...the things that interested me about this game? Disappointing.There's very little actual plot. The premise is you're the chosen one on a quest to save the land from the darkness. That's the exact language the game uses, and it thinks it's being clever as it bashes you over the head with it. It broadcasts its only real twist from minute one, and doesn't subvert this premise in any significant way. The ending is about twenty seconds long: nothing explained, a cheesy joke and a fade to black. ♥♥♥♥ that.Before playing this, I saw a few reviews that noted that the tone was all over the place. Which I thought would be interesting. The game cycles you through generic video game tropes, horror, and humor. Unfortunately, the writer isn't strong enough to juggle these ideas. The horror elements aren't scary enough, and the jokes not funny enough, to be welcome, interesting or justified. I couldn't shake the sense that Anodyne was a dumping ground for every single idea the developers had, but without a decent design plan the various pop culture references and spooooky uterus themed dungeons never become anything more than the sum of their parts.And it's all pointless anyway, since the game expects you to forget about these weird asides the moment they end. We're left with a very boring, standard video game fantasy plot with some token ambiguity about what it all might mean. But again, the writing is just not strong enough to make you care about that.If Anodyne had been free, I might have a more charitable opinion of it. It has some interesting ideas, but the developers lacked the ability or willingness to refine them. But I paid $3.50 for it and am walking away feeling profoundly ripped off. The idea of paying $10 for it makes me nauseated.

Posted: April 27, 2014
												This is for all of the people who are calling this game a Zelda rip-off:Look, I understand where you're coming from.  At many times I would see something in the game and go "OH, really showing your roots there Anodyne, might as well just call your last boss Ganon and slap on a green hat..."  but then, I did something that really helped me appreciate the game, and games in general, for that matter.  I stopped evaluating it with respect to other games.  I considered it by itself.  The art style is beautiful, and it's not fair to say that just because other games have succeeded using a pixel art aesthetic that Anodyne is just riding their coattails.  Is it true?  Maybe.  Is is a fair criticism?  No.  It's really not.  Look at the game again and tell me it isn't beautiful.  I spent so much time in the world of Anodyne not because I miss my old Link's Awaknening game, but because it was a world in which I truly enjoyed to be.  So, the moral of the story is this:  you can tell me that the game lacked meaning, or didn't appeal to you, or that you didn't like the art style or humor or direction or pacing or any other legitimate complaint.  Just at least give it the credit to evaluate it by its OWN merits.The platforming is fun and challenging, the myriad of ways in which the designers have you exploring the broom mechanic is brilliant, the characters are quirky and fun, the world is gorgeous, and I truly enjoyed every part of this game.  I would recommend this game a thousand times over.

Posted: April 16, 2014
												This is what you get when you mix the gameplay of the 2D Zeldas with the surrealness of something like EarthBound. I wasn't expecting much going in, but it ended up being enjoyable by the end of it. (Now if only we could open that 50-card door...)Anodyne has some strong points and good moments that I won't spoil here. It's worth the asking price if you're a fan of the 2D Zeldas, but it needs some polish to be truly *great*.For starters, as a first impression, when first running the game it asked me to adjust the window's size with the arrow keys (what game does this?), which couldn't even be held down to change the size and then proved to be completely useless when I could just change the settings to presets in the menu later. I understand this was originally made in Flash but the PC port should be more standardized with the resolution and other options.There's quite a few dead-ends that *look* meaningful, but are really nothing of use and that makes the world feel more empty than it should be. Also the overworld could have been much more interesting but instead is just a bunch of mostly arbitrarily-placed portals to the different levels, of which have no labels to identify them aside from the small screenshot of the area (heck, even the signs in the levels are worn away and as such don't tell you where you're going).My other critique would be that the pacing/story should be stronger. Finding the protagonist's signature broom is simply a plain chest in a plain room. The item itself is hilarious because there's nothing special about it and yet it's the weapon for the whole game, but the moment of getting it shouldn't have been so plain.Overall, Anodyne is fairly imprssive considering it was made in 10 months by 2 developers, but it could have used more polish to really stand out as something greater than a Zelda-inspired dungeon-crawler.

												Anodyne is one of these short sweet indie games that offer a great experience while it last. The story stars with a character named young waking up to find himself in a dreamrelm. He then comes across a sage who says he is the chosen one and must   defeat the creatures in order to escape. What makes the story special is how the bosses and NPC's seem to have different ideas about what is going on and sharing them with you. The gameplay is very similar to the old Legend of Zelda games. Both have an overhead view and use a weapon for stabbing your enemies. The main differences come with the limited items and main weapon. You use a broom throughout the game to dispatch enemies and activate switches and the only usable item you obtain is some jumping shoes that allow you to jump which is used allot in later areas. The game looks fantastic with a retro art style. It fits the world and setting nicely and the game isn’t afraid of some dark tones when it wants to. The settings are also quite unique where you find yourself in a hotel or a strange universe instead of your usual dungeons and temples. Music is nice most of the time and has some nice tracks that I wouldn’t mind downloading. Anodyne mages to bring back the dying overhead action adventure genre and does it in such a well way. The game may only be 5-6 hours long but it is well worth the money and it was only made by two guys in less than a year. Pick it up some time and experience it for yourself.

												Anodyne is a game which I bought for $3 along with a bundle of other assorted indie games. Having finished it, I can wholeheartedly recommend it, even at full price, for it imparts simplicity, solitude, and subtlety that I find rather underappreciated or ignored these days.The story, ostensibly about a human named Young attempting to protect "The Briar" from "The Darkness" that has spread across "The Land", would be rather uninteresting if it were not for how the game's description directly states that it all takes place within Young's subconscious. Resulting from this is a somewhat lonely journey which focuses more on succinct phrases rather than grandiose spiels and atmosphere over tangibility, overall akin to going through a series of dreams within a larger dream (which is no surprise as Yume Nikki is cited as one of the inspirations for this game). Later on in the game the ideas and caricatures presented occasionally get a bit too obtuse for me to understand, but the main theme of the plot is still clear and I was quite satisfied by the ending. Moreover, Anodyne never interrupts its gameplay for an extended period of time to exposit or pontificate, which is nice as it means players are not forced to care about the game's script if they do not want to. That would be a shame, however, as the multiple lines of dialogue from the game's NPCs and signs tend to be incredibly humorous or chilling, sometimes both at the same time.Mechanically, the game is not particularly complex; imagine Link's Awakening but with no items outside of the Sword and the Roc's Feather. Although Young gains several equippable upgrades throughout the course of the game, the majority of them just increase the range of his broom, and the enemy and obstacle counts are not particularly high either. As such, the majority of the game consists of exploring the overworld (surprisingly large and spanning multiple environments), slaying enemies (both passive and aggressive), clearing dungeons (about as much as you'd expect in a Zelda game), vanquishing bosses (all of them uniquely designed and fairly tough), and ultimately collecting cards which are required to progress further in the game.Nonetheless, the rooms of each dungeon tend to be designed well enough that old adversaries often offer new challenges. There are also some tricky puzzles and platforming sections as well, the latter sometimes becoming a bit too tricky due to the top-down perspective. Honestly though, there are only two points of contention I truly have with the gameplay. Firstly, the collection of said cards might put off players who do not enjoy backtracking and exploring EVERYWHERE. I was personally okay with it, though Young's mediocre movement speed made the task plodding at times. Secondly, the post-game is rather lackluster, basically furthering the card seeking with a late-introduced gimmick which can be hard to control along with literally exploiting glitches; it feels like an afterthought. Other than that, the simplicity of the game is a mark in its favor.Moving on to aesthetics, the game describes its visuals as "GBC/16-bit", which is certainly true and they are sprited very well in that style, but what really stood out to me were the gorgeous overlays that complimented many of the game's areas. I'm particularly a fan of the cliffs (pictured above), which are bathed in a warm sunset's glow, along with some later, gloomier areas which would be a shame to spoil. The sound design is excellent as well, especially the "Obtain Key" noise which is utterly jarring and I love it.Continued...

Posted: September 26, 2014
												This game retains both the gameplay feel of the original Zelda, and the quirkiness and psychological absurdity of Earthbound fused into one, mysterious and, at times, wonderful, RPG. For me, I think this game by its own merits is a very interesting game at the very least, with a unique feel to the artwork, and some of the most luscious, entrancing melodies I have ever heard in a videogame. They seem to shimmer with celestial mystery, and at other times, shift into quaint, innocent tunes which fits perfectly with the idylic, art inspired world. The fact that this game, was done by literally only two people is beyond incredible, and the complexity of the project and beauty of the music when looking at the budget and manpower attests to the ingenuity and imagination of the developers. However, there are some flaws which certainly makes me think this game often betrays good gameplay or even an entertaining story for overly abstract and 'out there' symbolism. The use of the broom, although an amusing play on the sound of Link's sword, makes for an especially boring weapon and means of interacting with the world. Never mind the grating sound as the broom emerges before you, the lack of any other notable weapons and tools (unlike Zelda which had a whole set of tools to diversify gameplay) makes being stuck with this weapon feel limiting and maddening at times. This same lack of variety also plagues the enemies, who don't necessarily feel special or unique enough to employ any more meaningful strategy than 'attack with your broom and hope for the best'. Having said this, whilst the combat gameplay feels beyond mundane, some of the puzzles are much more convincing, and reminded me of the good days of more challenging Zelda puzzles. In the end, definitely get this game and try it out, it is, in my opinion, one of the most innovative and atmospheric RPGs I've seen in a long time, but it is plagued by a few narrative decisions that seriously hinder the gameplay and a story that often seems to run away from concrete themes and ideas into the black abyss of abstract meaning. I seriously hope for the next game by these two talented developers, and hope they continue to pour resources to channel their amazing ideas into a more solid gameplay experience to match the incredible sophistication of the atmosphere and beauty their games attain.

												It’s pretty ok.An action adventure game in the vein of, and clearly inspired by Zelda games. The gameplay mechanics are fun and work well but don’t do much to expand on the basics of its genre. You only get one weapon for the game (a broom of all things) and while there are a few bits of equipment to gather the only new ability you get during the game is jumping. There’s no shield, no bow, no bombs and no spin attack, just you and your broom. And it does work quite well. There’s a good variety in both the enemies and bosses to keep things fun, even if it’s never extraordinary.The game has some nice puzzles as well. Familiar setups that would, in Zelda, be solved by finding a new item are instead solved by manipulating enemies in the area or finding a new use for your broom, which lets you move around surprisingly useful piles of dust in the name of puzzle solving. It’s occasionally quite clever but never really mentally taxing.What sets the game apart is its tone and world, though unfortunately not in a way I’m actually fond of. The world is made up of a series of interconnected areas, but as the game goes on each area starts to get steadily more weird and disconnected. The beach leads to an undersea area, which leads to a zombie filled labyrinth where the graphics suddenly switches from SNES to NES inspired, which leads to a circus (in a cave) filled with notes about people dying in horrible accidents. You wander from a black and white town filled with serial killers to an abstract region of space filled with holographic projections of sentient pyramids ruled over by two cubes who will talk to you about how their “rule” is utterly meaningless as they have no subjects. This in turn leads to a hotel themed dungeon because why not?What is the story linking all this? There isn’t really one, you just work your way through the areas, solve puzzles, defeat bosses and collect cards. At the start of the game the Village Elder (there is no village) tells our hero Young that he must save The Land from the Darkness. It’s hopelessly generic and the game is very much aware of that. There’s a borderline sarcastic aloofness about the whole thing. The Village Elder, despite sending you on your quest, doesn’t actually seem all that enthusiastic about your mission and actually starts to discourage you as things go on.The wrongness and flippancy of it all permeates throughout. A stone sign informs you that stones will never have something different to say if you interact with them more than once, but only when you interact with it a second time. Bosses that talk to you but don’t seem to actually have anything to do with the Darkness that you are supposedly fending off (but is in no way evident). A sign informs you that a parking lot was built in honour of the fact that the major couldn’t find anywhere to park. There’s occasional cursing that seems, to me, to only be there to highlight how jarring cursing is in a game that borrows so much from Zelda.None of this is ever tied up into anything that resembles sense or thematic coherency, at least not to me. Once you defeat the final boss the story shrugs its shoulders and gives you a signoff as opaque as everything preceding it.You do get an extra reward for finishing though - a new ability that allows you to practically tear the gameworld apart in order to traverse hidden areas and find secrets. To be honest though I didn’t feel much motivation to make use for it. A world that doesn’t make sense, and refuses to make sense, a world that revels in not being real rather than attempt to give you a sense of place, is not that interesting to me. And I didn’t particularly care about trying to tease out its last secrets. I think that this sort of thing was done better, and with more thematic relevance, in Porpentine’s Armada. And for that matter I think Armada did the flippant tone better too.This review has probably come across as very negative. Despite the lack of cohesion between areas, many of the areas are quite interesting to explore in and of themselves with some very clever ideas. I honesty did enjoy playing the game and working through it. It’s a consistently fun game even if it doesn’t do anything spectacular. It’s a game a profession reviewer would give a solid 7/10 because the standard game review scale is dumb as hell.

There often isn't enough of a perspective in Anodyne to really judge where you are in relation to the rest of the world, there are minimal invincibility frames at best when you're actually in the air, and there isn't any forgiveness when you go to touch back down. If your landing is not nearly pixel-perfect, be prepared to take damage, knockback, and/or fall and find yourself obliged to try again. It's a stark contrast from the Roc's Feather in the games that inspired Anodyne, which was the best item in those games precisely because it felt amazing to use. Jumping in Anodyne is anything but.There is a room prior to Card #48 in the debug world that makes every other platforming challenge in Anodyne look like fun by comparison. The footholds are smaller and there is a third roller, and if you screw up, you might accidentally leave the room when you respawn because the player's hitbox occasionally intersects with the view's boundaries when you fall into a pit and reappear. When that happens in the room leading to Card #48, it prevents you from finishing the series of platforming puzzles to acquire your reward and renders you incapable of either going forward or going back. You must commit suicide in order to try again from the beginning.The precision platforming in Anodyne isn't well-implemented and it isn't fun to play. While it's passable in the main game because it's not a major focus, neither quality makes for a fun achievement ("Lots of Cards") for completionists to hunt. The extras in Anodyne are not worth the effort it takes to gather them. I collected all of them; I know.

												This game is absolutely excellent, and a great experience for any action-adventure fan out there. It's already been three years since this game was launched, but when I beat it, I felt like I owed the developers this review.You play the game in the shoes of a character called Young, who is in a mysterious quest to reach something called a "Briar" with the help of a sage called Sage. In your way stands an amazing world full of secrets, puzzles, enemies and landscapes to explore, and treacherous guardians to fight your way through. When you go deep into the game's world, you'll notice that it is... a brilliant metaphor, which I won't spoil (not that there's much to spoil three years after the game's launch, but still, I'd rather let uninformed players figure it out by themselves).The game's world feels like a mix between Legend of Zelda and Yume Nikki, if that makes any sense. On one hand, it contains vast explorable maps with foes to fight aplenty, puzzles to solve, and items to collect, hence the Zelda comparison. On the other hand some of its maps are surreal, eerie and psychological, as though you were walking around a person's very fears and afflictions, hence the Yume Nikki comparison. The music always helps set the mood perfectly, sometimes being a simple eerie horror-like sound effect, and sometimes being beautifully composed tunes that go well with beautiful sections.During the adventure, our hero Young counts on a single weapon: his trusty broom, and a few extensions to it, that modify its range. There is also a jumping skill to get across treacherous holes in the ground, and another awesome skill that I'd rather not spoil. The fighting mechanics are not the most innovative I've ever seen, but they're pretty fun regardless. Most boss fights are rather easy and formulaic, but thankfully never boring.As for the dungeons, they're designed pretty well, making you solve simple puzzles, pick up keys to open up doors, backtrack to change the state of a switch or get a card you forgot, and ultimately reach the guardian of each area and beat it to a pulp. The dungeons occasionally get a bit redundant when, say, you see a button in a room that can only be reached by taking a long path through other rooms, and then going back to the same path to get to the door you opened, but that happens way less than necessary to make me frustrated.When the game ended, I simply didn't want to go. I wanted to stay... a little bit longer, it's hard to explain.Thankfully, though, I was delightfully surprised to know this game had even more content in the post-game, which is rife with awesome secrets to find and a near open world-like freedom.One thing I feel this game lacks, however, is the whole Zelda-like "key and keyhole" aspect. What I mean by that is in Zelda, upon getting a new tool, skill or weapon, you'll usually be pleased to realize that the item you just got can be used to get accross an obstacle you encountered previously, possibly to uncover a secret or to follow on to the next section of the game. In this game, however, the only situations where this happens (in a meaningful way) involve the jumping skill, which needs to be used in order to access an area in the Lake that leads to a card (said area, however, can also be reached by different means), and to reach the path that leads to the Briar. Sure, you also get to use trash from the ground as a raft, but that only comes up long after you already have the broom. This in particular bugs me a little, as I feel the game could be slightly better with a progressive "unfolding" of its world. I mean, sure, the lack of said "key and keyhole" obstacles meant that the game was more "open", meaning that one could go through the dungeons in many different orders according to their peference, but still, I feel like the developers could, perhaps, have included some optional sections with said unlockable obstacles, which you'd find on your way to each mandatory part of the game, so you can get back to them later, eager to see what they contain.In spite of that minor complaint, I'm still very glad I got this game, as it is enjoyable, interesting, deep and simply awesome. Even though it's not as Zelda-like as I expected, it's still worth any action-adventure enthusiast's time, and I couldn't recommend it enough.

												Anodyne is a game which I bought for $3 along with a bundle of other assorted indie games. Having finished it, I can wholeheartedly recommend it, even at full price, for it imparts simplicity, solitude, and subtlety that I find rather underappreciated or ignored these days.The story, ostensibly about a human named Young attempting to protect "The Briar" from "The Darkness" that has spread across "The Land", would be rather uninteresting if it were not for how the game's description directly states that it all takes place within Young's subconscious. Resulting from this is a somewhat lonely journey which focuses more on succinct phrases rather than grandiose spiels and atmosphere over tangibility, overall akin to going through a series of dreams within a larger dream (which is no surprise as Yume Nikki is cited as one of the inspirations for this game). Later on in the game the ideas and caricatures presented occasionally get a bit too obtuse for me to understand, but the main theme of the plot is still clear and I was quite satisfied by the ending. Moreover, Anodyne never interrupts its gameplay for an extended period of time to exposit or pontificate, which is nice as it means players are not forced to care about the game's script if they do not want to. That would be a shame, however, as the multiple lines of dialogue from the game's NPCs and signs tend to be incredibly humorous or chilling, sometimes both at the same time.Mechanically, the game is not particularly complex; imagine Link's Awakening but with no items outside of the Sword and the Roc's Feather. Although Young gains several equippable upgrades throughout the course of the game, the majority of them just increase the range of his broom, and the enemy and obstacle counts are not particularly high either. As such, the majority of the game consists of exploring the overworld (surprisingly large and spanning multiple environments), slaying enemies (both passive and aggressive), clearing dungeons (about as much as you'd expect in a Zelda game), vanquishing bosses (all of them uniquely designed and fairly tough), and ultimately collecting cards which are required to progress further in the game.Nonetheless, the rooms of each dungeon tend to be designed well enough that old adversaries often offer new challenges. There are also some tricky puzzles and platforming sections as well, the latter sometimes becoming a bit too tricky due to the top-down perspective. Honestly though, there are only two points of contention I truly have with the gameplay. Firstly, the collection of said cards might put off players who do not enjoy backtracking and exploring EVERYWHERE. I was personally okay with it, though Young's mediocre movement speed made the task plodding at times. Secondly, the post-game is rather lackluster, basically furthering the card seeking with a late-introduced gimmick which can be hard to control along with literally exploiting glitches; it feels like an afterthought. Other than that, the simplicity of the game is a mark in its favor.Moving on to aesthetics, the game describes its visuals as "GBC/16-bit", which is certainly true and they are sprited very well in that style, but what really stood out to me were the gorgeous overlays that complimented many of the game's areas. I'm particularly a fan of the cliffs (pictured above), which are bathed in a warm sunset's glow, along with some later, gloomier areas which would be a shame to spoil. The sound design is excellent as well, especially the "Obtain Key" noise which is utterly jarring and I love it.Continued...

												It’s pretty ok.An action adventure game in the vein of, and clearly inspired by Zelda games. The gameplay mechanics are fun and work well but don’t do much to expand on the basics of its genre. You only get one weapon for the game (a broom of all things) and while there are a few bits of equipment to gather the only new ability you get during the game is jumping. There’s no shield, no bow, no bombs and no spin attack, just you and your broom. And it does work quite well. There’s a good variety in both the enemies and bosses to keep things fun, even if it’s never extraordinary.The game has some nice puzzles as well. Familiar setups that would, in Zelda, be solved by finding a new item are instead solved by manipulating enemies in the area or finding a new use for your broom, which lets you move around surprisingly useful piles of dust in the name of puzzle solving. It’s occasionally quite clever but never really mentally taxing.What sets the game apart is its tone and world, though unfortunately not in a way I’m actually fond of. The world is made up of a series of interconnected areas, but as the game goes on each area starts to get steadily more weird and disconnected. The beach leads to an undersea area, which leads to a zombie filled labyrinth where the graphics suddenly switches from SNES to NES inspired, which leads to a circus (in a cave) filled with notes about people dying in horrible accidents. You wander from a black and white town filled with serial killers to an abstract region of space filled with holographic projections of sentient pyramids ruled over by two cubes who will talk to you about how their “rule” is utterly meaningless as they have no subjects. This in turn leads to a hotel themed dungeon because why not?What is the story linking all this? There isn’t really one, you just work your way through the areas, solve puzzles, defeat bosses and collect cards. At the start of the game the Village Elder (there is no village) tells our hero Young that he must save The Land from the Darkness. It’s hopelessly generic and the game is very much aware of that. There’s a borderline sarcastic aloofness about the whole thing. The Village Elder, despite sending you on your quest, doesn’t actually seem all that enthusiastic about your mission and actually starts to discourage you as things go on.The wrongness and flippancy of it all permeates throughout. A stone sign informs you that stones will never have something different to say if you interact with them more than once, but only when you interact with it a second time. Bosses that talk to you but don’t seem to actually have anything to do with the Darkness that you are supposedly fending off (but is in no way evident). A sign informs you that a parking lot was built in honour of the fact that the major couldn’t find anywhere to park. There’s occasional cursing that seems, to me, to only be there to highlight how jarring cursing is in a game that borrows so much from Zelda.None of this is ever tied up into anything that resembles sense or thematic coherency, at least not to me. Once you defeat the final boss the story shrugs its shoulders and gives you a signoff as opaque as everything preceding it.You do get an extra reward for finishing though - a new ability that allows you to practically tear the gameworld apart in order to traverse hidden areas and find secrets. To be honest though I didn’t feel much motivation to make use for it. A world that doesn’t make sense, and refuses to make sense, a world that revels in not being real rather than attempt to give you a sense of place, is not that interesting to me. And I didn’t particularly care about trying to tease out its last secrets. I think that this sort of thing was done better, and with more thematic relevance, in Porpentine’s Armada. And for that matter I think Armada did the flippant tone better too.This review has probably come across as very negative. Despite the lack of cohesion between areas, many of the areas are quite interesting to explore in and of themselves with some very clever ideas. 												This game is absolutely excellent, and a great experience for any action-adventure fan out there. It's already been three years since this game was launched, but when I beat it, I felt like I owed the developers this review.You play the game in the shoes of a character called Young, who is in a mysterious quest to reach something called a "Briar" with the help of a sage called Sage. In your way stands an amazing world full of secrets, puzzles, enemies and landscapes to explore, and treacherous guardians to fight your way through. When you go deep into the game's world, you'll notice that it is... a brilliant metaphor, which I won't spoil (not that there's much to spoil three years after the game's launch, but still, I'd rather let uninformed players figure it out by themselves).The game's world feels like a mix between Legend of Zelda and Yume Nikki, if that makes any sense. On one hand, it contains vast explorable maps with foes to fight aplenty, puzzles to solve, and items to collect, hence the Zelda comparison. On the other hand some of its maps are surreal, eerie and psychological, as though you were walking around a person's very fears and afflictions, hence the Yume Nikki comparison. The music always helps set the mood perfectly, sometimes being a simple eerie horror-like sound effect, and sometimes being beautifully composed tunes that go well with beautiful sections.During the adventure, our hero Young counts on a single weapon: his trusty broom, and a few extensions to it, that modify its range. There is also a jumping skill to get across treacherous holes in the ground, and another awesome skill that I'd rather not spoil. The fighting mechanics are not the most innovative I've ever seen, but they're pretty fun regardless. Most boss fights are rather easy and formulaic, but thankfully never boring.As for the dungeons, they're designed pretty well, making you solve simple puzzles, pick up keys to open up doors, backtrack to change the state of a switch or get a card you forgot, and ultimately reach the guardian of each area and beat it to a pulp. The dungeons occasionally get a bit redundant when, say, you see a button in a room that can only be reached by taking a long path through other rooms, and then going back to the same path to get to the door you opened, but that happens way less than necessary to make me frustrated.When the game ended, I simply didn't want to go. I wanted to stay... a little bit longer, it's hard to explain.Thankfully, though, I was delightfully surprised to know this game had even more content in the post-game, which is rife with awesome secrets to find and a near open world-like freedom.One thing I feel this game lacks, however, is the whole Zelda-like "key and keyhole" aspect. What I mean by that is in Zelda, upon getting a new tool, skill or weapon, you'll usually be pleased to realize that the item you just got can be used to get accross an obstacle you encountered previously, possibly to uncover a secret or to follow on to the next section of the game. In this game, however, the only situations where this happens (in a meaningful way) involve the jumping skill, which needs to be used in order to access an area in the Lake that leads to a card (said area, however, can also be reached by different means), and to reach the path that leads to the Briar. Sure, you also get to use trash from the ground as a raft, but that only comes up long after you already have the broom. This in particular bugs me a little, as I feel the game could be slightly better with a progressive "unfolding" of its world. I mean, sure, the lack of said "key and keyhole" obstacles meant that the game was more "open", meaning that one could go through the dungeons in many different orders according to their peference, but still, I feel like the developers could, perhaps, have included some optional sections with said unlockable obstacles, which you'd find on your way to each mandatory part of the game, so you can get back to them later, eager to see what they contain.In spite of that minor complaint, I'm still very glad I got this game, as it is enjoyable, interesting, deep and simply awesome. Even though it's not as Zelda-like as I expected, it's still worth any action-adventure enthusiast's time, and I couldn't recommend it enough.

												NOTE: This review is written 2 and a half years after playing; my memory may be somewhat foggy.Anodyne was... an interesting experience. Other reviews (even positive ones) seem to describe it as a bit bland and, despite enjoying it myself, I can agree.From the outset, Anodyne felt rather low-energy; there wasn't enough variety in the mechanics to make it feel engaging. The often empty environment and soundtrack gave the world an eerie, ethereal tone, which bored me a little at first instead of intriguing me. After the first time I played, I took around a week to get back to continuing it.That being said, why am I giving Anodyne a positive review?As I continued playing, the world grew on me. I wasn't aware of a clear, linear plot, although perhaps the game didn't need that, for what it was. The absurd settings I encountered led me to want to interpret what I was seeing, to figure out what was going on for myself even when I wasn't playing. I'll exclude any interpretations I came up with so you can form them on your own. When I beat the game, Anodyne left me with some indescribable feeling... Though I remember being bored at first, I can only look back on playing it fondly.In short: Anodyne is fairly simplistic in terms of gameplay. If you're expecting a Legend of Zelda clone, you're not really going to get it. It's the strange emotions resulting from the experience that sell Anodyne, for me; nothing you'd get an idea of from the store page.
